sn22.86:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn22.86:1.2: Now at that time Venerable Anurādha was staying not far from the Buddha in a wilderness hut.
sn22.86:1.3: Then several wanderers of other religions went up to Venerable Anurādha and exchanged greetings with him.
sn22.86:1.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to him:
sn22.86:1.5: “Reverend Anurādha, when a Realized One is describing a realized one—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them in these four ways:
sn22.86:1.6: After death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.”
sn22.86:2.1: When they said this, Venerable Anurādha said to those wanderers:
sn22.86:2.2: “Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a realized one—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:
sn22.86:2.3: After death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.”
sn22.86:2.4: When he said this, the wanderers said to him:
sn22.86:2.5: “This mendicant must be junior, recently gone forth, or else a foolish, incompetent senior mendicant.”
sn22.86:2.6: Then, after rebuking Venerable Anurādha by calling him “junior” and “foolish”, the wanderers got up from their seats and left.
sn22.86:3.1: Soon after they had left, Anurādha thought:
sn22.86:3.2: “If those wanderers were to inquire further,
sn22.86:3.3: how should I answer them so as to repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? How should I explain in line with his teaching, so that there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?”
sn22.86:4.1: Then Venerable Anurādha went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him all that had happened.
sn22.86:7.4: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.86:7.6: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.86:7.7: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.86:7.16: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’
sn22.86:8.2: Do you regard a realized one as form?”
sn22.86:8.4: “Do you regard a realized one as feeling …
sn22.86:9.2: Do you regard a realized one as in form?”
sn22.86:9.4: “Or do you regard a realized one as distinct from form?”
sn22.86:9.6: “Do you regard a realized one as in feeling …
sn22.86:10.2: Do you regard a realized one as possessing form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
sn22.86:11.2: Do you regard a realized one as without form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
sn22.86:12.1: “In that case, Anurādha, since a realized one is not found by you as a genuine fact in this very life, is it cogent for you to declare:
sn22.86:12.2: ‘Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a realized one—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:
sn22.86:12.3: After death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists’?”
sn22.86:13.2: In the past, as today, what I describe is suffering and the cessation of suffering.”
